content: The Act may be cited as the "Asthma Awareness, Education and Treatment Act of 1999". The Congress finds that asthma affects millions of Americans, with a significant impact on children and school absenteeism. The prevalence of asthma has increased over the years, especially among low-income families. Women and preschool children are particularly affected by this chronic respiratory disease. Asthma affects millions of Americans, with a significant impact on children and school absenteeism. The prevalence of asthma has increased over the years, especially among low-income families. In the United States, asthma costs over $12 billion annually, with a rising prevalence leading to higher future costs. African Americans are five times more likely to seek care for asthma at an emergency room. The asthma death rate is higher among African American children and adults. Exercise can improve the physical and psychological well-being of children with asthma. Regular physical activity can enhance an individual's quality and length of life. SEC. 3. Grants for asthma-related activities for low-income communities. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may provide grants to public and nonprofit entities for projects in low-income communities, including screenings, education, and workshops on asthma, allergies, and respiratory issues. Screenings and referrals must be comprehensive and offered in various settings like hospitals and clinics. The Secretary of Health and Human Services provides grants for projects in low-income communities focusing on asthma, allergies, and respiratory issues. Information and education on these conditions are provided in various settings, including hospitals, clinics, schools, community centers, and government offices. The education includes symptoms, prevention, and is tailored to the language and cultural context of the individuals. The Secretary provides grants for projects focusing on asthma, allergies, and respiratory issues in low-income communities. Information and education are provided in traditional and nontraditional settings, tailored to individuals' language and cultural context. Evaluation includes determining the number of children receiving screenings and referrals. The projects funded by the Secretary focus on asthma, allergies, and respiratory issues in low-income communities. Evaluation includes assessing the impact on individuals' prevention and management of these health issues, as well as the effectiveness of information and education materials. Grant applicants must be community-based organizations serving the target community or demonstrate substantial involvement of such organizations in project implementation. Applications for grants must be submitted in the required format to be considered for funding. Authorization of Appropriations: $8,000,000 for fiscal year 2000 and necessary sums for fiscal years 2001 through 2004 are authorized for carrying out the projects funded by the Secretary. The application must meet the Secretary's requirements to be considered for funding. The National Media Campaign to provide asthma-related information is authorized for funding. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may award contracts for a national media campaign to provide information on asthma, allergies, and respiratory problems, with a focus on children. The campaign must include information on prevention and management of these conditions, as well as resources available in communities for screenings, referrals, and treatment. It should be conducted in the most appropriate language and cultural context for the community. Authorization of Appropriations: $600,000 for fiscal year 2000, and necessary sums for fiscal years 2001 through 2004. Tax credit for donations of pest control and climate control services under SEC. 45D of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Taxpayers providing pest control or climate control services can receive a donation credit equal to 10 percent of the costs incurred in offering qualified services for free in public housing or low-income multifamily residential properties. Taxpayers offering pest control or climate control services can receive a donation credit for providing qualified services in public housing or low-income multifamily residential properties. The services must be part of a good faith effort to achieve the intended result and verified as prescribed by the Secretary. Pest control and climate control services include eliminating pests and improving ventilation and temperature control. Amendments to the tax code allow for a donation credit for taxpayers engaged in providing these services. Amendments to the tax code restrict the carryback of the section 45D credit before January 1, 2000. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1999. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with the EPA, will conduct research to determine the link between air pollutants and asthma, allergies, and respiratory issues. Priority will be given to clinical evaluations for individuals in low-income communities. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with the EPA, will conduct research to determine the link between air pollutants and health issues, with a focus on low-income communities. This research is guided by budget regulations set by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget. SEC. 7. COORDINATION OF FEDERAL ACTIVITIES TO ADDRESS ASTHMA-RELATED HEALTH CARE NEEDS. The Director of the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute will identify federal programs for asthma, develop a federal response plan, and submit recommendations to Congress. The Department of Housing and Urban Development will have a representative on the coordinating committee. $5,000,000 will be allocated to the National Asthma Education Prevention Program. Funds allocated to the National Asthma Education Prevention Program for fiscal years 2000-2004 will be in addition to any other appropriations during that period. The Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, in consultation with the National Asthma Education Prevention Program Coordinating Committee, will conduct local asthma surveillance activities to collect data on asthma prevalence, severity, and management. This includes telephone surveys and health care facility specific surveillance. They will also compile and publish data on the prevalence of children with asthma in each State and the childhood mortality rate associated with asthma nationally and in each State.
